thread.title: Brisbane International: Raonic, Cilic, Muguruza confirmed
thread.title_full: Brisbane International: Raonic, Cilic, Muguruza confirmed

author: PAUL MALONE
title: Brisbane International: Raonic, Cilic, Muguruza confirmed
text:
Video Image Rafael Nadal survives early scare in Shanghai 1:06 Tennis: Rafael Nadal survives an early scare against Croatian Ivo Karlovic to progress to the third round of the Shanghai Masters
October 15th 2015 6 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/Tennis/ Milos Raonic of Canada will play at the Brisbane International.
PAUL MALONE The Courier-Mail THE Brisbane International now boasts four of the top dozen men in tennis, with the recruitment of Canadian Milos Raonic and former US Open champion Marin Cilic.
Raonic, 24, is the youngest man in the top 10 and dragged Roger Federer to a deciding set in the Pat Rafter Arena final last January before Federer took out his landmark 1000th career win.
Federer (ranked third), Japan’s Kei Nishikori (No.6), Raonic (9) and Cilic (12) are the early male entries to the Brisbane tournament, which starts on January 3.
Maria Sharapova is the top female seed.
Hampered by foot and back injuries through the sport’s prime Wimbledon-to-US Open weeks of the year, the big-hitting Raonic won his first title of the year this month in St Petersburg, Russia.
Milos Raonic will play at the Brisbane International. Source: Reuters
Beaten by Nick Kyrgios at Wimbledon, Raonic nonetheless underlined his credentials in a difficult 2015 season by posting two wins over Stan Wawrinka and one over Rafael Nadal.
“I’m playing much better. I’m getting ahold of my game,’’ he told reporters in Russia.
“I’ve definitely been putting in the work this year. It hasn’t turned out for me as far as a health standpoint.
“There’s many road bumps, and it’s about the way you deal with things.’’
Cilic was a late withdrawal from last summer’s Brisbane International due to a shoulder injury which eventually kept him off the ATP tour until April.
“I’m fresh at the end of this season and it will help me in the new season,’’ Cilic said in a statement to Tennis Australia.
Marin Cilic is Brisbane-bound. Source: Reuters
“I always enjoy playing in Brisbane. The fans are sports enthusiasts.
“Brisbane is a small tournament, but with huge crowds. It’s always a packed house and that’s great for the players.’’
Cilic made a good fist last month of defending his surprise US Open title, but ran aground in a straight-sets semi-final loss to eventual champion Novak Djokovic at Flushing Meadows.
In his first tournament since losing the final to Djokovic five weeks ago, Federer crashed to a 7-6 (7-4), 2-6, 6-3 loss to world No.70 Albert Ramos-Vinolas at the ATP Shanghai event on Tuesday.
The Spanish qualifier had lost all 15 of his previous matches against top-10 opponents and the result gives Federer pause for thought as he looks to extend a long season.
The Wimbledon and US Open runner-up is scheduled to wrap 2015 up at the ATP Finals in London, starting on November 15, before his short off-season break.
Cilic posted an impressive 6-1, 6-2 win over his highly-rated fellow Croatian Borna Coric, ranked 40th.
Spain's Garbine Muguruza will play in Brisbane. Source: Getty Images
Wimbledon finalist Garbine Muguruza will add depth to the women’s field.
Muguruza enjoyed a breakout 2015, reaching her maiden grand slam final at the All England Club, in which she was defeated by Serena Williams.
“Wimbledon was amazing but I don’t want to have a lot of expectations for 2016,” she said.
“I want to keep the same, improving and thinking about every tournament and every match, because this is when I will improve and be better, just no expectations and be calm.”
 Hot men’s field for Brisbane Int
